title: Web of undersea cables becomes marine observatory: a revolution in the protection of marine mammals
summary: In the depths of the oceans, where the sun's light never penetrates, lies a network of undersea cables that connect the world. These cables, which are essential for our global telecommunications, are now poised to play a new, crucial role: they are being transformed into marine observatories. This innovative initiative aims to protect vulnerable marine mammals and give us insight into their behavior and habitat. It is a revolutionary step forward in oceanography and the conservation of marine ecosystems. The undersea cables, previously used solely for data transmission, are now being equipped with advanced sensors and technologies that can collect real-time information about the environment. These sensors can measure sounds, temperature, salinity, and currents. This enables scientists to gather detailed data about the habitat of marine mammals such as whales, dolphins, and seals. One of the key applications of this technology is the monitoring of the sounds produced by these animals. Marine mammals often communicate through sound, and by analyzing these sounds, scientists can better understand their behavior, migration patterns, and social interactions. This is invaluable for the conservation of these species, as many are threatened by human activities such as traffic noise, pollution, and climate change. Additionally, the sensors can also help detect threats to these animals, such as ship traffic and underwater construction activities. By analyzing this data in real-time, authorities can quickly intervene to prevent damage. Another advantage of using undersea cables as marine observatories is the ability to monitor large areas. Since these cables span vast distances, they can cover a wide range of marine ecosystems. This provides scientists with a unique perspective on the dynamics of the oceans and the interactions between different species. The initiative is also an example of how existing infrastructure can be repurposed for new purposes. Instead of building new, expensive research stations, this project utilizes existing cables, making it both cost-effective and sustainable. This is an important consideration in an era where budgets for scientific research are often limited. The impact of this project on the conservation of marine mammals can be enormous. By gaining a better understanding of their habitat and behavior, scientists and policymakers can develop better strategies to protect these species. This can range from creating protected areas to implementing measures to reduce noise pollution. The project is also a step forward in international cooperation. Since undersea cables often run through multiple countries, this initiative requires collaboration between different countries and organizations. This can lead to improved coordination and exchange of knowledge in the field of marine conservation. Although the project is still in its early stages, the potential applications and benefits are already clear. The use of undersea cables as marine observatories is an innovative and promising approach to protecting the oceans and their inhabitants. It is an example of how technology and science can work together to protect nature and expand our knowledge of the world around us. It is a step forward in the right direction, and it is an initiative that deserves attention and support from the international community. In the coming years, we will likely see more such innovations, where existing technologies are repurposed for new, sustainable purposes. This is an exciting time for oceanography and the conservation of marine ecosystems, and the use of undersea cables as marine observatories is just the beginning.

title: Smartwatches can help detect heart rhythm disorders: 'Faster intervention'
summary: In an era where technology and healthcare are increasingly intertwined, a recent study by the Amsterdam UMC brings a promising discovery to light. Smartwatches, long a staple of our daily lives, can now also play a crucial role in detecting heart rhythm disorders. This marks a significant advancement in how we monitor and treat heart health. The study shows that these smart devices can recognize heart rhythm disorders that people might not even feel, leading to earlier diagnosis and treatment, which can ultimately save lives. The results of this research are not only important for patients but also for doctors and researchers seeking innovative ways to combat heart diseases. In this article, we delve deeper into the details of the study, its impact on healthcare, and what this means for the future of heart rhythm monitoring. The Amsterdam UMC, one of the leading medical centers in Europe, has conducted thorough research into the effectiveness of smartwatches in detecting heart rhythm disorders. The study included a diverse group of participants, including people with and without known heart problems. The results were convincing: smartwatches could accurately detect abnormalities in heart rhythm, often before the patients themselves experienced symptoms. This is a groundbreaking discovery, as it means smartwatches can serve as an early warning system for heart rhythm disorders. One of the key advantages of using smartwatches for heart rhythm monitoring is the continuity of monitoring. Unlike traditional methods, such as an ECG, which are only performed at specific times, smartwatches can track the wearer's heart rhythm 24/7. This provides a much more comprehensive picture of heart health and can help detect abnormalities that might otherwise go unnoticed. Additionally, smartwatches are easily accessible and can be seamlessly integrated into daily life. This makes them an ideal tool for preventive healthcare, especially for those at risk of heart rhythm disorders. The impact of this discovery on healthcare is enormous. By detecting heart rhythm disorders earlier, doctors can intervene more quickly and start the appropriate treatment. This can lead to better outcomes for patients and a reduction in the complications often associated with heart rhythm disorders. Furthermore, early detection of heart rhythm disorders can help lower healthcare costs, as patients will need to be hospitalized less frequently. The Amsterdam UMC study also highlights the importance of collaboration between technology companies and medical institutions. By combining their expertise, they can develop innovative solutions that improve healthcare. This is an example of how technology can contribute to a healthier future for everyone. The future of heart rhythm monitoring looks promising, thanks to the continuous advancements in technology and medical research. Smartwatches are just the beginning; there are already new developments on the horizon, such as advanced algorithms and artificial intelligence, which can further improve the accuracy and effectiveness of heart rhythm monitoring. It is important that we embrace these technologies and use them to improve our health. The Amsterdam UMC study is a significant milestone in the development of smartwatches as a tool for heart rhythm monitoring. It shows that these devices are not only useful for tracking fitness goals but can also play a life-saving role in healthcare. By detecting heart rhythm disorders earlier, we can save lives and improve the quality of life for patients. It is an exciting time for healthcare, and we can look to the future with confidence.

title: NFI Breaks Barriers: Fatal Morphine Overdose Now Detectable Even Months After Death
summary: In a revolutionary breakthrough for forensic science, the Netherlands Forensic Institute (NFI) has achieved a milestone that will forever change how we investigate overdoses. Researchers can now detect a fatal morphine overdose even if the person has been dead for months, thanks to new techniques. This is a significant leap forward from the previous limit of only four weeks post-mortem. The implications of this discovery are enormous, both for justice and healthcare. The NFI, based in The Hague, is renowned worldwide for its innovative approach to forensic investigations. This latest breakthrough is no exception. The team of researchers has spent years improving methods to analyze drug-related fatalities. The new technique employs advanced analytical methods that enable the detection of morphine, a potent opioid, in tissues and organs even after a prolonged period of decomposition. This is invaluable for solving complex cases where the cause of death is not immediately apparent. One of the key benefits of this new method is that it empowers justice systems to re-examine older cases. There are countless situations where a morphine overdose might have been overlooked because the analysis was conducted too late. With this new technique, researchers can now look back and potentially solve previously unsolved cases. This can lead to justice for victims and their families, who may have waited years for answers. Furthermore, this breakthrough can contribute to a better understanding of the prevalence of morphine overdoses in society. By analyzing older cases, researchers can identify patterns and trends that might otherwise go unnoticed. This can lead to better prevention and treatment strategies for drug use and abuse. The impact of this discovery also extends to healthcare. Doctors and medical personnel can now better understand how morphine works in the body, even after a prolonged period of decomposition. This can lead to improved treatment methods and a better understanding of the consequences of opioid use. The NFI has already begun sharing their findings with other forensic institutions and research teams around the world. This international collaboration is crucial for improving forensic methods and solving complex cases. The future of forensic science looks bright, thanks to the relentless efforts of researchers like those at the NFI. Their work is a testament to the power of science and innovation in the pursuit of truth and justice. The NFI's breakthrough is a milestone in forensic science and a hopeful step forward in solving drug-related fatalities. It is a triumph of human endeavor and technological advancement, pushing the boundaries of what is possible. With this new technique, we can now better understand and solve complex and challenging cases, contributing to a safer and more just society.

title: Revolution in Education: VU Introduces AI Hologram as a Legal History Teacher
summary:
In a groundbreaking step towards the future of education, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) has launched an innovative project: an AI-driven hologram as a teacher for legal history. This hologram, named Lex Frisius, is a virtual legal scholar from the eighteenth century who introduces students to the world of law. This development marks a significant shift in the way education is given and received, opening the door to a new era of interactive and technology-driven learning experiences.

Lex Frisius is designed to guide students through a lively and interactive presentation of historical legal data. The hologram uses advanced artificial intelligence to respond to student questions, engage in discussions, and explain complex legal concepts in an understandable way. This innovation allows students to communicate directly with a virtual expert, providing a unique and engaging learning experience.

The introduction of Lex Frisius is not only a technological breakthrough but also a strategic move to adapt education to modern learning forms. In an era where technology plays an increasingly important role in our daily lives, it is essential that education adapts to prepare students for the future. By integrating AI and holographic technology into the educational process, VU creates a learning environment that is both innovative and effective.

Student reactions have been overwhelmingly positive. Many students have noted that interacting with Lex Frisius has improved their understanding of legal history and that they feel more engaged in the learning process. The ability to communicate directly with a virtual expert allows students to develop their knowledge at a deeper level and have their questions answered immediately.

Of course, there are also critical voices. Some wonder if a hologram can ever replace a real teacher. While Lex Frisius is a powerful tool, the developers emphasize that the hologram is intended to improve education, not to replace traditional teachers. The goal is to provide a supplement that helps students learn better and feel more engaged in their studies.

VU is not alone in this innovation. Universities around the world are experimenting with new technologies to improve education. From virtual reality to AI-driven learning platforms, the future of education looks like an exciting mix of technology and traditional learning principles. The introduction of Lex Frisius is a step in that direction, and it is exciting to see how this technology will further develop and transform education.

In conclusion, the introduction of Lex Frisius by Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam is a groundbreaking development with the potential to revolutionize education. By integrating AI and holographic technology, VU creates a learning environment that is both innovative and effective. While there is still much to learn about the impact of this technology, it is clear that it is a powerful tool that can improve education and help students reach their full potential.

title: Fewer colorectal cancer diagnoses thanks to population screening: a success story
summary: Over the past ten years, there has been a notable decrease in the number of people diagnosed with colorectal cancer. This is a surprising result, as an increase was expected due to the aging population. The decrease is a result of the population screening for colorectal cancer, reports the Integraal Kankercentrum Nederland (IKNL). This screening, which has been conducted since 2014, has proven itself to be an effective means of early detection and treatment of colorectal cancer. The population screening is an example of how preventive measures can have a significant impact on public health. The screening targets people between the ages of 55 and 75, a group in which colorectal cancer is most prevalent. Participants receive a test kit at home, with which they can take a stool sample. This sample is then analyzed for the presence of blood, which can indicate colorectal cancer. If the sample is positive, further investigation follows, often with a colonoscopy. Early detection is crucial in colorectal cancer, as the disease is often treatable in its early stages. Thanks to the population screening, tumors are more frequently detected in an early stage, significantly improving survival rates. This has a positive effect not only on the individual patient but also on healthcare as a whole. Fewer advanced cases of colorectal cancer mean fewer heavy treatments and lower costs for healthcare. The success of the population screening is also due to the high participation rate. Although there are always people who postpone the screening or do not participate, the general response is positive. Many people appreciate the simplicity and comfort of the home screening. IKNL emphasizes the importance of participation, as early detection can save lives. The decrease in colorectal cancer cases is a fine example of how science and healthcare can work together to improve public health. The population screening for colorectal cancer is a success story that hopes to be continued and expanded to other forms of cancer. It is an inspiring example of how prevention and early detection can contribute to a healthier future for everyone.

title: Jacob Elordi: The Star Who Rejects Social Media
summary: Jacob Elordi, the 28-year-old Australian actor, is everywhere right now—except on social media. With his notable roles in series like 'Euphoria' and films such as 'Saltburn' and 'Priscilla', Elordi has established himself as one of Hollywood's most in-demand young actors. Yet, he chooses to keep his private life out of the reach of social media, a choice that is increasingly being made by more young actors and Generation Z individuals. In an interview with CBS Sunday Morning, Elordi stated, 'I have no relationship with social media.' This statement comes not only from an actor who values his privacy but also from someone who consciously chooses a life outside the spotlight of the digital world. Elordi's refusal to lose his life to the industry of social media is a testament to his dedication to his craft and his desire to lead an authentic life. 'My dream was to be an actor. My dream was to play in movies, and I'm too nervous to ask for more than that. I've been given exactly what I wanted, and I see it exactly how I dreamed it, and I live it how I dreamed it. For me, that's about all I can handle.' These words provide a deep insight into Elordi's philosophy on life and career. He has had an Instagram account in the past but often deactivates it. His account has been deactivated since late 2024. For Elordi, staying offline is a way to prevent Hollywood from taking over his entire identity. Despite his growing fame, he says that this boundary allows him to move through his private life mostly undisturbed. 'I have a pretty strong refusal to lose my life to an industry, you know. I consider myself an actor and nothing more. And so for me, life kind of goes on outside the set, outside these lights and cameras and things. I don't have too much trouble in the world.' Elordi's approach to his career and private life is a breath of fresh air in an industry often driven by social media and public attention. He emphasizes that he does not see himself as a Hollywood star but as an actor living his passion. 'It doesn't really factor into my reality, you know. I have so much love in my life, and the relationships I have in my life are so present and real. I was raised in such an authentic and true way. I feel so deeply here that, I don't know, the idea of this industry and stuff—it doesn't really factor into my day-to-day.' Elordi's stance is not unique. More and more Generation Z individuals, both within and outside of Hollywood, are choosing to live a life less dependent on social media. Mia Threapleton, the daughter of Kate Winslet, revealed in 2025 that her mother encouraged her to make a list of pros and cons for creating an Instagram account when she was 14. 'The cons completely outweighed the pros for me. That was quite a clarifying moment. Since then, I'm really happy that I don't have it.' This trend is not limited to Hollywood. Many Generation Z individuals are trading smartphones for 'dumb phones', using their mobile phones as landlines, and organizing 'anti-social media' parties where no one is allowed to scroll. This movement reflects a growing recognition of the negative effects of social media on mental health and well-being. Jacob Elordi's choice to stay offline is not only a personal statement but also a symptom of a broader cultural shift. It is a declaration of independence and a refusal to be defined by the digital world. In a time when social media has become an integral part of the lives of many, Elordi's approach is a reminder of the value of privacy and authenticity. His success in Hollywood, despite his absence on social media, is proof that it is possible to have a significant career without succumbing to the pressure of digital presence. Elordi's story is an inspiration to young actors and Generation Z individuals seeking a balance between career and private life. It underscores the importance of maintaining a healthy relationship with technology and prioritizing authentic human connections over virtual validation. In a world increasingly dominated by screens and likes, Jacob Elordi's choice to stay offline is a breath of fresh air and a reminder of the value of a life outside the digital bubbles.

title: Gong Cha's Battle: How a Bubble Tea Chain Leveraged Starbucks' Success
summary:
In the world of entrepreneurship, it's not uncommon to learn from the successful strategies of others. Martin Berry, the founder and chairman of Gong Cha, has embraced this principle and turned it into a global bubble tea empire. His story is an inspiring example of how strategic location choice and a unique offering can lead to spectacular growth. Gong Cha, a brand known for its fragrant, fruity teas and its milk foam topping, now has nearly 2,200 stores in 33 countries. But how did it all begin?

Berry's journey started in 2011 when he and his wife invested $2.5 million of their savings to open the first five Gong Cha franchise stores in South Korea. It was a risky move, as Berry quit his banking job to go all in on bubble tea. But his strategy was brilliant. He decided to open the first five Gong Cha stores right next to Starbucks outlets. His reasoning was simple but effective: if he could convince just one in a hundred customers who visited Starbucks to try Gong Cha, he would have a successful business.

This strategy was not only a clever marketing move but also a testament to Berry's belief in the product. He knew that once customers had tasted the unique flavor of Gong Cha's bubble tea, they would return. And so it happened. The first five stores were a huge success, and Gong Cha began to expand rapidly. Today, it is a global chain with a strong presence in various countries, including the United States and Canada.

Gong Cha's success is not unique in the world of bubble tea. Other brands, such as Mixue and Luckin Coffee, have also achieved great success. Mixue, the global fast-food chain that sells cheap bubble tea and ice cream, has more than 45,000 stores worldwide and opened its first outlet in New York at the beginning of the year. Luckin Coffee, another Asian beverage brand, has positioned itself as a competitor to Starbucks, offering similar drinks at lower prices. Luckin Coffee expanded to the United States last year, with several outlets in New York.

The growth of bubble tea brands is a testament to the global popularity of this drink. It is not just a trend but a phenomenon that continues to grow. And Gong Cha, with its strategic location choices and unique products, is one of the key players in this market. Berry's story is an inspiring example of how a smart strategy and belief in the product can lead to spectacular growth and success.

In an interview with CNBC, Berry spoke about his journey and how he expanded Gong Cha from a small brand in Taiwan to a global chain. He talked about the challenges and the triumphs, and how he learned from the successful strategies of others. His story is an inspiring example of how an entrepreneur can grow and adapt to the changing market.

Gong Cha's success is not only a testament to Berry's vision and strategy but also to the power of franchising. By using franchising, Gong Cha was able to expand rapidly and build a strong presence in various countries. This has not only promoted the growth of the brand but has also given local entrepreneurs the opportunity to participate in Gong Cha's success.

The future of Gong Cha looks bright. With its strong presence in various countries and the growing popularity of bubble tea, the brand is well-positioned to continue growing. And with Berry at the helm, it is clear that Gong Cha will continue to innovate and adapt to the changing market. His story is an inspiring example of how an entrepreneur can grow and adapt to the changing market, and how a smart strategy and belief in the product can lead to spectacular growth and success.

title: Snowflake's CEO warns: software giants risk becoming a 'dumb data pipe' to AI models
summary: In a recent interview, the CEO of Snowflake, Sridhar Ramaswamy, issued a warning that calls into question the future of software companies in the shadow of the rise of artificial intelligence (AI). Ramaswamy, who took the helm of Snowflake in 2024 after his time as a partner at Greylock Ventures and as co-founder of the AI search engine Neeva, shares his insights on the Big Technology Podcast by Alex Kantrowitz. His warning is clear: the largest software companies risk becoming mere data sources for AI labs, while they themselves are reduced to 'dumb data pipes' that feed data into the 'big brains' of AI models. This is a scenario that not only threatens the future of software companies but also the way businesses manage and use their data. Ramaswamy emphasizes that AI companies like OpenAI are striving to consolidate enterprise data in one place, shifting control and access to data from the companies themselves to the AI labs. This consolidation could lead to a situation where software companies lose their value if they only function as data suppliers. To prevent this, Ramaswamy advocates for a solution where customers retain control over their data and decide for themselves how they want to access their information. This would mean that companies can choose direct access via their own agents or through products like ChatGPT. The rise of AI labs as software providers is a recent development that threatens traditional software companies. OpenAI, for example, has recently entered the sales, support, and document analysis market, putting pressure on companies like Salesforce and Oracle. Despite these developments, Anish Acharya, general partner at Andreessen Horowitz, warns that software companies are being unfairly punished by Wall Street out of fear that AI will take over their industry. Acharya emphasizes that legacy software cannot be easily replaced because it is not profitable to use AI for every business function. He points out that software accounts for only 8% to 12% of business costs, making the savings from using AI limited. Instead, companies should focus on developing their core businesses and optimizing other costs. The warnings from Ramaswamy and Acharya come at a time when software stocks have had a brutal start to the month, dragging down tech and broader markets. The sell-off began when already-wary investors panicked over Anthropic's new AI tool, which can perform a range of clerical tasks for people working in the legal industry. The impact of these developments on the software industry is significant. If software companies lose their value and are reduced to data suppliers, this would not only affect their profit margins but also their innovation potential. This could lead to a situation where control and access to data are entirely in the hands of AI labs, limiting competition and choice for businesses. To prevent this, it is essential that software companies maintain their value by investing in innovation and providing customers with the means to manage and use their data in a way that best suits their needs. This could mean that software companies develop new products and services that help customers use their data effectively, such as advanced analytical tools or integrations with AI models. It is also important that software companies collaborate with AI labs to ensure that their products and services are compatible with the latest AI technologies. Through this collaboration, software companies can maintain their value and provide customers with the means they need to succeed in a world where AI plays an increasingly important role. The warnings from Ramaswamy and Acharya are a wake-up call for the software industry. It is essential that software companies maintain their value and provide customers with the means to manage and use their data in a way that best suits their needs. By investing in innovation and collaborating with AI labs, software companies can strengthen their market position and provide customers with the means they need to succeed in a world where AI plays an increasingly important role.

title: Trump's trade advisor demands Big Tech to bear the cost of AI data centers
summary: In a recent interview on Fox News' 'Sunday Morning Futures', Peter Navarro, trade advisor to President Donald Trump, stated that big technology companies must bear the full cost of their AI infrastructure. Navarro emphasized that data center builders must 'internalize the costs' their AI infrastructure creates, such as electricity, water, and grid strain. According to him, companies 'need to pay for all of the costs', and taxpayers should not bear the impact of AI growth. The White House must ensure that the American people are not disadvantaged, Navarro said. These comments come as the AI data center boom faces increasing scrutiny over rising utility bills. Tech giants are pouring hundreds of billions into infrastructure to power artificial intelligence. In November, Meta pledged $600 billion to expand AI technology, infrastructure, and its workforce. Apple said in August it would boost its US infrastructure plans by adding another $100 billion, bringing its total commitment to $600 billion. Meanwhile, energy costs are rising. Electric and gas utilities sought $31 billion in rate hikes from regulators last year, more than twice the $15 billion requested the year before, according to a study published last month by PowerLines, a nonprofit that advocates for utility customers. Many power providers have cited surging electricity demand from large-scale data centers as a key reason for seeking higher rates. President Donald Trump has pushed back on the idea that households should absorb those increases. 'I never want Americans to pay higher Electricity bills because of Data Centers,' the president wrote last month in a post on Truth Social. The 'big technology companies who build them,' the president said, 'must pay their own way.' Navarro also said on Fox News that the US must keep expanding its data center capacity if it wants to remain 'No.1 on the global stage in terms of AI.' 'We have to lead China and others on this,' Navarro said. 'At the same time, we have to be mindful of the impacts across this nation.' The US must stay ahead 'not just for economic reasons but for national security reasons,' because AI 'will be one of the most dangerous weapons of war,' he added. Some AI companies have moved to reassure policymakers that households won't bear the cost of the industry's rapid expansion. Anthropic said on Thursday that it will cover 100% of the grid upgrade costs associated with its AI data centers. 'The country needs to build new data centers quickly to maintain its competitiveness on AI and national security,' Anthropic said. 'But AI companies shouldn't leave American ratepayers to pick up the tab.' The pledge follows the company's November announcement that it plans to invest $50 billion in AI infrastructure, starting with facilities in Texas and New York. Microsoft has taken a similar approach. Last month, the company said it would pay utility rates high enough to cover the electricity costs tied to its data centers and minimize the burden of data center expansion on surrounding communities.

title: A Gen Zer drained her savings building a startup. A 6-figure job at Meta helped her start over — then she quit.
summary: When Alyson Isaacs joined Meta in 2022, she had about $200 in her savings account after exhausting her funds on a startup. A six-figure salary offered a chance to rebuild her finances, but her ultimate goal lay outside Big Tech. After college, Isaacs 'completely drained' her savings on a startup she'd co-founded, and found herself grappling with her next career move. After weighing her options, she decided to follow the advice of a mentor: go to 'startup rehab' — in other words, take a full-time job. 'You can always get a job at a Big Tech company,' said Isaacs, who's 28 and lives in San Francisco. About four months later, she landed a product manager role at Meta in the company's Quest for Business virtual reality division. But her entrepreneurial itch never left, and she eventually began mapping out the best path back into the startup world. 'There are ways you can be entrepreneurial,' she said of working at Big Tech, 'but it's very much not the same.' Over the past year, I've interviewed more than a dozen workers who, like Isaacs, chose to quit their jobs at major employers — in some cases without another role lined up. While some eventually landed at another large company, others stepped away from the corporate world entirely — joining a smaller business, launching their own venture, pursuing a career pivot, or focusing on personal priorities like parenting. They've become outliers in an economy where workers are quitting at one of the lowest rates in the past decade — a trend driven by a hiring slowdown that's left some clinging to their jobs with few appealing alternatives. Those who have called it quits told me they did so for a mix of reasons: concerns about job security, shifts in workplace culture, entrepreneurial ambitions, or a desire for more meaningful work. In short, they wanted greater long-term agency over their careers. Isaacs shared how she decided to take the leap back into entrepreneurship — and offered advice for others facing a similar career crossroads. Business Insider is speaking with workers who've found themselves at a corporate crossroads — whether due to a layoff, resignation, job search, or shifting workplace expectations. Share your story by filling out this form, contacting this reporter via email at jzinkula@businessinsider.com, or via Signal at jzinkula.29. After leaving her post-college startup, Isaacs took a month to reset. She then spent two months interviewing at smaller companies to fine-tune her résumé and sharpen her interview skills. Eventually, she applied for a role at Meta and landed the job. She moved from the Berkeley area to San Francisco and started in May 2022 — about a year after graduation. While Isaacs didn't have firm plans to return to entrepreneurship, she knew that if she ever went down that path again, she'd need to be financially prepared for life without a steady paycheck. So she started living well below her means, including living in a less expensive area, going to a basic gym, cooking at home, and avoiding shopping sprees. 'I saved so hard because I knew that this wasn't going to be the end game for me, and I wanted to start my own thing again eventually,' she said. Isaacs also prepared for a potential return to entrepreneurship by spending about five hours a week angel investing, which involved scouting and backing startups. After about a year of saving, she began making a few investments, each under $10,000. She said the experience helped her build a network in San Francisco's startup scene and spot gaps other entrepreneurs could exploit — insights that helped shape her own business ideas. The final phase of Isaacs' preparation was soaking up everything she could from her time at Meta, including transitioning to a product manager position at Instagram — one of Meta's subsidiaries — in 2024. She said the roles gave her knowledge and experience that entrepreneurship alone couldn't provide. 'Traditional entrepreneurship was just flying by the edge of my seat and seeing what worked,' she said. 'But I needed that level of expertise to go farther in my career.' The question was when to make the leap and leave Meta. Isaacs said the death of her father in 2024 weighed heavily on her thought process. 'That really triggered this thought in my brain of, 'Is being a product manager at a Big Tech company what I want to do for the rest of my life?'' she said. 'And the answer was resoundingly no — I wanted to do something on my own and prove myself.' By mid-2025, Isaacs found herself thinking more and more about a startup idea in the consumer AI space — and struggling to focus on her job at Meta. On July 1, she resigned; the next day, she began working full-time on her startup, which she described as an 'agentic AI solution for personal wellness.' The company is currently in stealth, meaning the team isn't publicly sharing full details while the product is still in development. She said she and her two co-founders are testing the product with users and plan to open a pre-seed funding round in the spring. Isaacs said she knows many people might hesitate to give up a Big Tech job. But she believes some underestimate their chances of finding a new role or building something themselves — and end up stuck in jobs they don't enjoy. 'It's kind of like dating,' she said, adding that if you anticipate a bad dating pool, 'you're going to stay with your bad ex.' Isaacs said she wasn't worried about resigning from Meta, in part because she's a 'super optimist' about her career. If her startup doesn't work out, she's confident in her backup plan — the same one she relied on after her post-college startup opportunity fell through. 'Leaving Meta wasn't scary for me because I was like, 'I can always get another job in Big Tech,' she said. Isaacs has a few pieces of advice for other aspiring entrepreneurs. She recommends connecting with as many people as possible who are relevant to the venture you want to pursue — and looking for ways to help them, whether through angel investing, advising, or offering support. 'You kind of create this flywheel of people helping you if you help other people first,' she said. Additionally, even if your end goal is to build a business, Isaacs said having experience at a big-name company can give you valuable credibility as an entrepreneur. 'I needed to be undeniable as a founder, and having a big-box name brand on your résumé gives you that undeniability,' she said.

title: Electronic coach revolutionizes ski jumping: Technology as the key to Olympic gold
summary:
In the world of ski jumping, where every fraction of a second can be decisive, revolutionary technology brings a new dimension of precision and feedback. An electronic coach, designed to help ski jumpers optimize their performance, is poised to transform the sport. This article explores how this technology works, what it means for the future of ski jumping, and whether it can ever replace the traditional coach.

The decisive moment during ski jumping, the takeoff, lasts only fractions of a second. In that short time, a ski jumper must do everything perfectly: the right posture, the perfect timing, and the maximum power. Errors in these fractions of a second can make the difference between a medal and a disappointing performance. The new technology, developed by a team of engineers and sports scientists, makes this crucial moment measurable and provides immediate feedback. This enables ski jumpers to refine their technique and improve their performance.

The electronic coach works using advanced sensors and cameras that track every movement of the ski jumper. This data is processed and analyzed in real-time, providing the ski jumper with immediate feedback on their performance. The technology can, for example, detect if the ski jumper takes off too early or too late, or if their posture during the flight is not optimal. This feedback allows ski jumpers to quickly improve their technique and optimize their performance.

One of the main advantages of this technology is that it enables ski jumpers to analyze and improve their performance even when their coach is not present. This is particularly useful for ski jumpers who train in remote areas or who do not have the means to afford a full-time coach. The electronic coach can also be used to track the progress of a ski jumper over time, giving coaches and athletes a better insight into the effectiveness of their training.

But can this technology ever replace the traditional coach? While the electronic coach is a powerful tool, it cannot fully replace the human touch and experience of a seasoned coach. A coach can not only provide feedback on technique but also motivate, develop strategies, and mentally prepare a ski jumper for competitions. Moreover, a coach can better understand and adapt to the unique needs and strengths of a ski jumper.

Nevertheless, the electronic coach offers a valuable addition to traditional coaching. It enables ski jumpers to optimize their performance and refine their technique even when their coach is not present. It can also be used to track the progress of a ski jumper over time, giving coaches and athletes a better insight into the effectiveness of their training.

The future of ski jumping may lie in a combination of traditional coaching and advanced technology. The electronic coach can be a powerful tool to help ski jumpers optimize their performance and refine their technique. But it is the human touch and experience of a seasoned coach that can ultimately make the difference between a good and an outstanding performance. In the years to come, we will likely see that the electronic coach becomes an integral part of the training of ski jumpers, alongside traditional coaching. This will not only improve the performance of ski jumpers but also transform the sport as a whole.

title: Hollywood Shaken by AI Video Model Seedance 2.0 Revolution
summary:
Hollywood, the global leader in entertainment, is being shaken to its core by a new technological breakthrough. This time, it's not TikTok, but Seedance 2.0, an AI video model developed by ByteDance, that is causing a stir in the film industry. Disney, one of the biggest players in the sector, has already approached ByteDance to explore this innovation. But what makes Seedance 2.0 so revolutionary and why is Hollywood so concerned?

Seedance 2.0 is an AI tool that enables the creation of hyper-realistic videos with multiple shots in one. Imagine being able to upload a photo of Brad Pitt and Tom Cruise and then have them engage in an epic fight scene on a rooftop. Or you could create a video of Mickey Mouse battling Thor. The possibilities are endless, and the quality of the videos is so high that it's nearly impossible to distinguish them from real videos.

The impact of Seedance 2.0 on the film industry is enormous. It has the potential to completely change the way films are made. Instead of lengthy and expensive shoots, filmmakers can now simply use an AI tool to create the desired scenes. This can not only significantly reduce production costs but also foster the creativity of filmmakers, as they can now experiment with scenes that would otherwise be impossible to film.

However, technological advancement brings challenges. One of the biggest concerns is the potential for misuse. With Seedance 2.0, anyone, even without any film knowledge, can create hyper-realistic videos. This opens the door to deepfake videos and other forms of deception. Hollywood and other entertainment companies must be aware of these risks and take measures to prevent misuse.

Another challenge is the impact on employment in the film industry. As AI tools like Seedance 2.0 become more widely used, traditional film jobs, such as actors, directors, and camera operators, may become obsolete. This could lead to a significant change in the job market and the need for retraining and adaptation.

Despite these challenges, Seedance 2.0 also offers enormous opportunities for innovation and growth. It can completely change the way we consume entertainment. Imagine being able to watch a personalized, custom-made film specifically for you, instead of going to a movie theater. This is no longer science fiction but a reality that is increasingly becoming a possibility.

Hollywood faces a crucial choice. They can embrace technological advancement and leverage the possibilities of Seedance 2.0 to elevate the film industry to new heights. Or they can try to hold back technological progress, which ultimately leads to falling behind and losing competitiveness. The choice is clear: embrace the future or fall behind.

title: Retreating to a Connecticut Convent With the ‘Order of Hospitality’
summary:

The convent, surrounded by the tranquil nature of Connecticut, offers a unique combination of spirituality and hospitality. The Bridgettines, an order with roots dating back to the 14th century, have always been committed to providing a safe and peaceful place for anyone seeking a time of quiet and reflection. Their guest houses, scattered around the world, are open to travelers of all faiths, offering a unique and inclusive experience.

Towey describes her arrival at the convent as a moment of immediate calm. Meals are not only a moment of nourishment but also of community and connection. In addition to spirituality and hospitality, the convent also offers the opportunity for relaxation and reflection. Towey took advantage of the peaceful surroundings to read, write, and meditate. She describes how the nature around the convent, with its forests and lakes, formed a perfect backdrop for her personal reflection.

Towey’s article is a captivating description of a stay in a convent where hospitality and spirituality come together. It is an invitation to pause from the hustle and bustle of daily life and enjoy the simple but profound experiences that life in a convent offers. title: Our Editors Love Wearing Jeans on the Plane—Yes, Really
summary:
In the world of air travel, where comfort and style often clash, our editors have made an unexpected but welcome discovery: jeans. Yes, you read that right. Jeans, the timeless, versatile pant, is the unlikely hero of the modern air travel wardrobe. But why? And how have our editors brought this denim dream to life? Let's dive into the world of comfortable, stylish air travel with jeans.

First and foremost, let's make one thing clear: not all jeans are created equal for air travel. It's about finding that perfect fit, the right material, and the ideal comfort levels. Our editors have spent hours researching, testing different brands and styles, and ultimately finding their favorite jeans that meet all the criteria. These are jeans that don't pinch, don't squeeze, and feel comfortable even after a long flight.

One of the key factors our editors considered was the fit. A too-tight fit can be uncomfortable and make you feel self-conscious, while a too-loose fit might not make you look as stylish. The perfect fit is one that is comfortable, allows for free movement, and looks good too. Our editors have found that a straight or slightly wide fit works best for air travel. This type of fit provides enough room for your legs to sit comfortably without feeling restricted.

The material of the jeans is another crucial factor. Our editors have discovered that jeans made from high-quality denim, which is slightly stretchy, work best. This type of denim provides enough support and comfort without feeling too stiff or too heavy. It's also important that the jeans breathe well so you don't get too hot during the flight. Our editors have noticed that jeans with a small percentage of elastane or spandex often work best because this makes the jeans slightly more stretchy and provides extra comfort.

In addition to the fit and material, our editors also looked at the style of the jeans. While comfort is key, you naturally want to look good too. Our editors have found that jeans in classic colors, such as blue, black, and gray, work best for air travel. These colors are versatile and can be easily combined with different outfits. They are also suitable for both more formal and informal occasions, depending on how you style them.

Another aspect our editors considered is the sustainability of the jeans. In an era where sustainability is becoming increasingly important, it's important to choose jeans that are not only comfortable and stylish but also eco-friendly. Our editors have discovered that there are more and more brands producing sustainable jeans, made from organic bleached denim or recycled material. These jeans are not only good for the environment but also offer the same level of comfort and style as traditional jeans.

But how do our editors actually wear their jeans on the plane? Let's take a look at a few of their favorite outfits. One of our editors loves to wear a pair of straight, blue jeans with a simple white t-shirt and a comfortable yet stylish jacket. This outfit is perfect for a long flight because it's comfortable but also looks good. Another editor prefers to wear a pair of black jeans with an elegant blouse and a light washed sweater. This outfit is perfect for a shorter flight or a business traveler who wants to wear something stylish but still comfortable.

Our editors have also discovered that jeans are perfect for air travel because they can be easily refreshed. A pair of jeans can be simply folded and packed into a carry-on bag, giving you an extra outfit to hand. This is especially handy if you plan to go straight to an appointment or event after your flight. With a pair of jeans and a few different tops, you can create a number of different outfits, ensuring you're always stylish and comfortable, wherever you go.

Of course, there are a few things to keep in mind when wearing jeans on the plane. First, make sure your jeans aren't too tight as this can be uncomfortable during a long flight. Second, choose jeans made from high-quality denim that breathe well so you don't get too hot. Third, choose a fit that is comfortable and allows for free movement. And finally, remember that style and comfort go hand in hand. You don't have to choose between the two; you can have both with the right jeans.

In conclusion, our editors have discovered that jeans are the perfect choice for air travel. Whether you're looking for comfort, style, or both, there's a pair of jeans out there that's perfect for you. With the right fit, the right material, and the right style, you can ensure you're comfortable and stylish, wherever you go. So, the next time you're traveling, consider packing a pair of jeans. You'll be surprised at how comfortable and stylish they can be.

title: 8 Best Hikes in Mallorca to Explore the Balearic Isle
summary:
Mallorca, the largest island of the Balearics, is a paradise for hikers. With its diverse landscapes, ranging from spectacular coastlines to serene mountains, the island offers a wide range of hiking trails for every level. Whether you are an experienced trekker or seeking a leisurely walk, Mallorca has something to offer everyone. Here are eight of the best hikes you must undertake to truly experience the island.

The Torrent de Pareis is one of the most iconic hikes in Mallorca. This 13-kilometer route begins in Sa Calobra, a picturesque village on the west coast, and follows a spectacular gorge. The hike is moderate to difficult, but the reward is the breathtaking views over the gorge and the surrounding mountains. It is a challenging but unforgettable experience you should not miss.

For those seeking a shorter but equally spectacular hike, the walk to the Puig de Galatzó is an excellent choice. This 7-kilometer route begins in Es Capdellà and leads you to the top of the Puig de Galatzó, one of the highest peaks of the island. The hike is moderate in difficulty and offers breathtaking views over the surrounding valleys and the Mediterranean Sea. It is a perfect hike for those seeking a challenge without going too far.

The walk to the Castell d'Alaro is another popular option. This 3-kilometer route begins in Alcúdia and leads you to the ruins of a medieval castle. The hike is easy and suitable for families and beginners. It is a great way to discover the history of the island while enjoying the beautiful natural surroundings.

For those who want to explore the coast, the Camí de Cavalls is an excellent choice. This 135-kilometer route circumnavigates the entire island and offers breathtaking views over the coastlines and the surrounding mountains. You can choose a part of the route that suits your level, from a short walk of a few hours to a multi-day trek.

The hike to Sa Calobra is another spectacular option. This 6-kilometer route begins in Sa Calobra and leads you to the top of the mountain. The hike is moderate in difficulty and offers breathtaking views over the gorge and the surrounding mountains. It is a perfect hike for those seeking a challenge without going too far.

The hike to the Torrent de Pareis is another iconic route. This 13-kilometer hike begins in Sa Calobra and leads you through a spectacular gorge. The hike is moderate to difficult, but the reward is the breathtaking views over the gorge and the surrounding mountains. It is a challenging but unforgettable experience you should not miss.

The hike to the Puig de Galatzó is another popular option. This 7-kilometer route begins in Es Capdellà and leads you to the top of the Puig de Galatzó, one of the highest peaks of the island. The hike is moderate in difficulty and offers breathtaking views over the surrounding valleys and the Mediterranean Sea. It is a perfect hike for those seeking a challenge without going too far.

Finally, the walk to the Castell d'Alaro is a great option for those seeking a short but spectacular hike. This 3-kilometer route begins in Alcúdia and leads you to the ruins of a medieval castle. The hike is easy and suitable for families and beginners. It is a great way to discover the history of the island while enjoying the beautiful natural surroundings.

Mallorca is an island full of amazing hikes you should not miss. Whether you are an experienced trekker or seeking a leisurely walk, there is something for everyone. Lace up your hiking boots and discover the beauty of the Balearics.

title: From 10% to 47%: Cardiac Arrest Survival Rates Rise in Texas City Empowering Citizens to Save Lives
summary:
Over the past two years, the city of McKinney, Texas, has significantly improved cardiac arrest survival rates through a coordinated effort between its fire and police departments, and now its citizens. Two years ago, the chances of surviving a cardiac arrest in McKinney were just 10 percent, similar to many U.S. cities. Today, that number has risen to 47 percent, an impressive improvement that has saved the lives of many residents. This article explores how McKinney achieved this remarkable feat and what other communities can learn from their success. 

The key to the improved survival rates in McKinney lies in a combination of quick response times, advanced medical training, and a strong focus on community engagement. The city's fire and police departments have enhanced their collaboration to treat cardiac arrest incidents more swiftly. They have also installed an extensive network of automated external defibrillators (AEDs) at strategic locations throughout the city, empowering citizens to respond quickly to emergencies. 

One of the most notable aspects of McKinney's success is the involvement of its citizens. The city has set up a comprehensive program to train residents in basic first aid, with a focus on CPR and the use of AEDs. Through these training sessions, citizens can effectively intervene in emergencies before emergency services arrive. This has not only improved survival rates but also fostered a sense of community and responsibility among residents. 

The impact of these efforts is evident in the numbers. Over the past two years, the number of cardiac arrest incidents successfully treated has significantly increased. The improved collaboration between emergency services and the active involvement of citizens have ensured that McKinney now has one of the highest cardiac arrest survival rates in the United States. 

The experience of McKinney offers valuable lessons for other communities looking to improve their own survival rates. By investing in training, technology, and community engagement, cities can enhance their response to emergencies and save lives. McKinney's successes demonstrate that a coordinated effort between emergency services and citizens can make a significant difference in the health outcomes of a community. 

In conclusion, the improved cardiac arrest survival rates in McKinney, Texas, are the result of a coordinated effort between emergency services and citizens. By investing in training, technology, and community engagement, the city has achieved an impressive improvement that can serve as a model for other communities. McKinney's successes show that saving lives is possible through collaboration and investment in the health and safety of the community.

title: Chinese river shows remarkable recovery after 70 years of decline
summary: The world-renowned Yangtze, the longest river in Asia and the third longest in the world, is showing significant signs of improvement. After seventy years of decline, the water quality of the river has significantly improved. This remarkable recovery is due to an effective fishing ban implemented by the Chinese government. The success of this initiative is a bright spot in the fight against environmental pollution and biodiversity loss. The Yangtze, which flows through three different climate zones and plays a crucial role in the lives of millions of people, has been a victim of industrialization and unsustainable agricultural practices for years. The river was heavily polluted by waste, chemicals, and heavy metals, leading to a dramatic decline in fish populations and a disrupted ecological balance. The fishing ban, which was introduced in 2003, was a radical but necessary measure to allow the river to recover. The ban covers an area of more than 70,000 square kilometers and includes over 400 species of fish. This has not only led to an increase in fish populations but also to an improvement in water quality and a restoration of ecological balance. Scientists have found that the concentration of heavy metals and chemicals in the water has decreased, while oxygen levels have increased. This has led to a recovery of water plants and animals, which in turn has contributed to improved water quality. The success of the fishing ban is not only due to the Chinese government but also to the local communities that have actively contributed to the protection of the river. Through educational programs and cooperation projects, local communities have been made aware of the importance of a healthy river and the role they can play in its preservation. The recovery of the Yangtze is a remarkable success story that hopes to inspire other rivers and waterways around the world. It shows that with the right measures and a combined effort of governments, scientists, and local communities, even the most polluted rivers can be restored. It is a bright spot in the fight against environmental pollution and biodiversity loss, and a beautiful example of how humans and nature can work together for a healthier future.

title: Asked my fiancée to marry me twice: a story of love and renewed commitment
summary: In a world full of traditions and conventions, the story of Jamie Evan Bichelman is a breath of fresh air. He has asked his fiancée not once, but twice, to marry him. An act that many people might consider unnecessary or even strange, but for Bichelman, it was a way to renew his love and commitment in a unique and meaningful way. Let's dive into his story, which is not only a story about repeating a proposal, but also about growth, self-improvement, and the power of love. Bichelman's story begins with a first proposal that, although it was a yes, wasn't quite perfect. There were factors that influenced the moment, such as the presence of unsupportive people and his own mental and physical health not being at its best. These factors made the moment, although it was a yes, not quite have the magical feeling he had hoped for. Bichelman describes how, while looking at the photos of that day, he sees the pain in his eyes and realizes that he and his fiancée deserve a second chance. A chance to create a moment that is entirely focused on their love, without the shadows of self-consciousness or unsupportive relationships. And so begins the plan for a second proposal. Two years later, after a period of growth and self-improvement, Bichelman decides to ask his fiancée to marry him again. This time, he chooses a location that is full of magic: Disneyland. It's a place that his fiancée has always loved, and it seems like the perfect location to celebrate their love. The day begins with a drive to Anaheim, California, with a bubbly Disney playlist as the soundtrack. They have a wonderful time at Disneyland, and within the magical confines of Main Street, USA, Bichelman goes down on one knee and renews his vow of love. He presents a piece of jewelry that matches the ring she already has, and they celebrate with a vegan meal surrounded by her favorite Disney characters. It's a day full of magic and love, and it's clear that the proposal wasn't necessary, but it was certainly worth it. It gives them even more beautiful memories to look back on, and it's a memory that is entirely about them and their love. Bichelman's story is a reminder that love and commitment can be expressed in different ways. It doesn't always have to be about a perfect moment, but about a moment that is meaningful to you and your partner. It's a story that challenges us to think about the traditions we follow and whether they really fit who we are and what we want. It's a story that shows us that it's okay to deviate from the norm, to find our own path, and to celebrate our love in our own way. And perhaps, like Bichelman, you'll find that a second proposal is exactly what you and your partner need to renew your love and commitment in a new and meaningful way.

title: Epstein Files: A List of People Facing Consequences Over the DOJ's Release
summary: The U.S. Department of Justice's release of over 3 million pages of Jeffrey Epstein-related documents has caused a new wave of backlash for people associated with the disgraced financier. The documents have revealed friendly communications with Epstein, even after his 2008 conviction for sex offenses. Some of the people who've experienced fallout exchanged crude messages about women, shared government secrets, or had a more expansive relationship with him than previously known. One high-profile entertainment industry executive said he wanted to see Ghislaine Maxwell in 'bondage gear' — well before any public accusation that she facilitated Epstein's sex-trafficking operation. It's not the first time the vast trove of documents, broadly known as the Epstein files, has had consequences for his associates. Last fall, the release of tens of thousands of Epstein's emails by the House Oversight Committee led to Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor being stripped of his title as a British royal. Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers took a leave from his teaching duties at Harvard University while the school investigates; he also resigned from OpenAI's board. Here are 10 people who've experienced consequences following the Justice Department's January 30 data dump. None of the people featured in this story has been accused of participating in Epstein's sex-trafficking scheme. Kathy Ruemmler, Goldman Sachs's chief legal officer, turned in her resignation following weeks of scrutiny over her communications with the convicted sex offender. June 30 will be her last day as the Wall Street bank's chief legal officer and general counsel, the bank said on Thursday. The DOJ's latest tranche of documents showed her offering Epstein advice on his legal troubles, including lawsuits brought by women accusing him of sexual abuse. She gushed over expensive gifts from him, including a $9,350 Hermes handbag, and referred to him in an email as 'Uncle Jeffrey.' She has previously said her relationship with the convicted sex offender was 'a professional association' and has expressed 'regret' over it. In the statement to Business Insider about her resignation, Ruemmler said it was her duty 'to put Goldman Sachs' interests first.' Brad Karp, a high-powered corporate lawyer, resigned as chairman of Paul Weiss, calling reports about his relationship with Epstein a 'distraction' for the white-shoe law firm. He also stepped down from the board of trustees of his alma mater, Union College. The documents include emails showing he worked with Epstein to surveil a woman in a dispute with one of Karp's clients. Business Insider has confirmed that the client was billionaire private equity titan Leon Black, who counted Epstein among his advisors. Karp also visited Epstein's Manhattan mansion and asked him to help his son get a job with director Woody Allen. Representatives for Paul Weiss declined to comment beyond their press release announcing Scott Barshay as the law firm's new chair. Peter Attia, a CBS News contributor and longevity expert, stepped down as the chief science officer of David Protein, a protein bar brand, and is no longer an adviser to the sleep technology company Eight Sleep. In the emails from the mid-2010s, Attia gives Epstein health advice that included crude remarks about women. In one email, he said a woman's genitalia was 'low carb.' In a social media post, he denied involvement in any criminal activity and said the emails were 'embarrassing, tasteless, and indefensible.' Howard Lutnick, the U.S. Commerce Secretary, is facing bipartisan calls from lawmakers to resign after emails show he planned a visit to Epstein's island with his family in 2012. Lutnick previously said he severed ties with Epstein, his former Manhattan neighbor, after first meeting him in 2005. 'My wife and I decided that I will never be in the room with that disgusting person ever again,' Lutnick told the New York Post last year. Lawmakers asked Lutnick about the discrepancy on Tuesday at a prescheduled Senate hearing over broadband. He testified that he, his wife, and kids were at the island 'for an hour' for lunch. The DOJ's files show the two men exchanged calls in 2011 and invested in the same company around the time of the island visit. The White House has stood by Lutnick, with the Commerce Department saying: 'Mr. and Mrs. Lutnick met Jeffrey Epstein in 2005 and had very limited interactions with him over the next 14 years.' Steve Tisch, owner of the New York Giants, exchanged numerous emails with Epstein about women in 2013, triggering a review by the National Football League. The emails show Epstein updating Tisch on the women, including their ages, nationalities, and 'working girl' status. After the emails were made public, he said he regretted associating with Epstein and that the women discussed in the emails were adults. NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell has said the league will review the communications and weigh whether they violate its personal conduct policies. Casey Wasserman announced on February 13 that he is selling his talent agency after his name appeared in the Epstein files, sparking a growing fallout. Soccer player Abby Wambach and singer Chapell Roan earlier said they were parting ways with Wasserman's agency. Wasserman flew on Epstein's jet with a group of people that included former President Bill Clinton. The files also show Wasserman and Ghislaine Maxwell exchanging racy and flirtatious emails in 2003, well before police began investigating Epstein, and over a decade before Maxwell's arrest on sex-trafficking charges in 2020. 'Casey - I will be coming back to NY torn late afternoon,' Maxwell wrote in one email. 'I shall be wearing a tight leather flying suit.' Wasserman said in a statement that he regretted his messages with Maxwell, which took place 'long before her horrific crimes came to light' and that he never had any personal or business relationship with Epstein. Wasserman announced his intentions to sell his agency in a memo to staffers, which the agency shared with Business Insider. 'I'm deeply sorry that my past personal mistakes have caused you so much discomfort. It's not fair to you, and it's not fair to the clients and partners we represent so vigorously and care so deeply about,' Wasserman wrote. 'The pain experienced by the victims of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell is unimaginable - and I'm glad, as I'm sure you all are, that those who helped them commit their crimes are rightly being held accountable.' Wasserman wrote that he had 'become a distraction.' 'That is why I have begun the process of selling the company, an effort that is already underway. During this time, Mike Watts will assume day-to-day control of the business while I devote my full attention to delivering Los Angeles an Olympic Games in 2028 that is worthy of this outstanding city,' he wrote. Sarah Ferguson, the ex-wife of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor, formerly known as Prince Andrew, shut down a charity she chaired following the Justice Department's document dump. A spokesperson for the foundation, called Sarah's Trust, said the decision was made after 'months' of discussion. The records show Ferguson sent warm emails to Epstein in 2009, when he was imprisoned for soliciting sex from a minor. She referred to him as the 'brother I have always wished for' and signed off another email with 'love you.' Ferguson previously said she regretted any association with Epstein. Representatives for Ferguson didn't respond to requests for comment. Peter Mandelson quit his job as the United Kingdom's ambassador to the United States, and left the British Labour Party itself, after the Epstein files showed him providing sensitive government information to the convicted sex offender. The emails, dating back to Mandelson's time in senior posts under former prime ministers Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, show him informing Epstein about a change in tax rules, the sale of government assets during a UK financial crisis, and a European Union bailout of Greece's economy. The records also show Epstein sent money to Mandelson's husband, Reinaldo Avila da Silva. London's Metropolitan Police said it's investigating Mandelson over the emails appearing to leak financial information to Epstein. Mandelson has denied any illegal activity and told The Times of London that his husband accepting the funds from Epstein reflected 'a lapse in our collective judgment.' Morgan McSweeney resigned as the chief of staff for British Prime Minister Keir Starmer over Mandelson, whom he recommended for the ambassadorship job. 'I advised the prime minister to make that appointment and I take full responsibility for that advice,' McSweeney said in a statement upon his resignation on Sunday. 'In public life responsibility must be owned when it matters most, not just when it is most convenient. In the circumstances, the only honourable course is to step aside.' Sultan Ahmed bin Sulayem was replaced as chairman and CEO of Dubai-based logistics firm DP World on February 13, after emails between the Emirati executive and Epstein were published by the Justice Department. DP World, which is owned by Dubai's royal family, is one of the world's largest logistics companies and runs Jebel Ali, the largest port in the Middle East. The company did not mention bin Sulaymen in its statement announcing a leadership transition, but said that Essa Kazim and Yuvraj Narayan would take on his roles as chairman and CEO, respectively. Emails published by the Justice Department show that Epstein referred to bin Sulayem as his 'close personal friend' in a 2010 email. In an email to Epstein in 2015, bin Sulayem said that a girl he met 'two years ago' who went to the American University in Dubai was 'the best sex I ever had amazing body.' Representatives at DP World did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for comment.

title: From Chaos to Joy: Embracing Motherhood of Two Children
summary: The life of a parent changes drastically when a second child arrives. What once was an organized and calm environment suddenly becomes a storm of chaos, noise, and haste. The author of the article on Business Insider shares her experiences and insights on the transition from one to two children, and how she learned to embrace the chaos and find joy in the motherhood of two children. The author describes how she thought she had motherhood figured out until her second child arrived. She was calm, patient, and well-organized with one child, but with two children, everything became messier, louder, and more rushed. She realized that parenting two children introduces a whole new dynamic, not only in her life but also in the relationship between her children. The author shares her struggle to adapt to the new circumstances and how she learned to embrace the chaos as a way to survive. She describes the challenges of caring for two children with different, urgent needs and how she often feels like she is caring for a dozen creatures. Despite the challenges, the author finds joy in the chaos. She describes how she enjoys the little trails her children leave behind and how she looks forward to picking them up from daycare, even though she knows it will be pandemonium from the moment they see her. The author emphasizes the importance of embracing the chaos and finding joy in the little things, even in the motherhood of two children. She concludes with a message of hope and optimism, and encourages other parents to embrace the chaos and find joy in their own journey of motherhood.

title: When retirement is 19 credit cards and $40,000 in debt away - Susan Cannon is struggling to pay off her credit card debt due to the high interest rates.
summary:
Susan Cannon is backed against the wall. The 73-year-old widow from Texas has 19 credit cards with a total debt of $39,440. The interest rates vary from 12.15% to 34.99%. 'I can't get the balance down because I am still having to use credit cards at the end of the month to get groceries and gas,' says Cannon. She pays her bills, but due to the high interest rates, the debt keeps growing. 'I feel like I'm being gouged.'

Cannon has worked hard her entire life. She started her career as a medical coder and later worked for Coca-Cola and as an accountant. After retiring in 2015, she worked part-time as a mystery shopper. But when the pandemic hit, she lost that job. Since then, she has lived off her social security, her pension, and minimal COVID relief. Credit cards helped her stay afloat, but the high interest rates made it difficult to pay off the debt.

Cannon hopes that a cap on interest rates will help her. President Donald Trump recently proposed capping credit card interest rates at 10%. Cannon believes this would make a significant difference for her. She has already contacted some banks to lower her interest rates, but to no avail. She recently received a denial letter from CitiBank, where she has an interest rate of 28.49%.

Interest rates on credit cards have been rising over the past decade. The average stands at nearly 23% annually, according to the New York Federal Reserve. Adam Rust, director of financial services at the Consumer Federation of America, says that credit card companies are 'incredible profit machines' that attract consumers with specific products. 'Those cards benefit from having a consumer who's captive to using that card in that store to get that deal,' says Rust. 'And so perhaps it's not surprising that interest rates are frequently higher as a result.'

Cannon has always made sure to pay at least the minimum monthly payment on her credit cards to keep from falling too far behind. She uses her social security check to cover about half of her bills, and at the end of each month, she finds herself transferring some money from her savings account into her checking account to cover the remainder of her expenses. This leaves her with just enough to pay slightly more than those minimum credit card payments, but nothing extra. 'I have tried to keep up with these credit cards, and I still am,' says Cannon. 'I feel like a fool, but at the same time, I wouldn't be in this situation if they hadn't raised those interest rates.'

Credit card interest rates are a rare issue that has garnered bipartisan agreement. The 2009 CARD Act required companies to notify customers of interest rate increases at least 45 days in advance and placed restrictions on actions such as late fees and withdrawal fees. However, the legislation did not cap interest rates or rate increases. That's why there's been a renewed push to cap interest rates. Trump called for a one-year, 10% cap on rates in early January, saying in a Truth Social post that he would 'no longer let the American Public be ripped off' by Credit Card Companies that are charging Interest Rates of 20 to 30%, and even more.

More recently, over 55 organizations, including the Consumer Federation of America and the NAACP, called on House and Senate lawmakers to pass bipartisan legislation that would cap credit card interest rates at 10% for 5 years. Research from Vanderbilt University found that the proposal could save $100 billion a year. Credit card companies have pushed back on the proposed caps. A coalition of banking groups said in a joint statement in response to Trump's proposal that a 10% cap 'would reduce credit availability and be devastating for millions of American families and small business owners who rely on and value their credit cards, the very consumers this proposal intends to help. If enacted, this cap would only drive consumers toward less regulated, more costly alternatives.'

Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan's CEO, said on a recent earnings call that capping credit card rates could limit access to credit for customers with lower credit scores. Those more costly alternatives include payday loans, which tend to charge high interest rates and fees that can be a lot more difficult for consumers to escape than credit cards, Rust said. SoFi's CEO, Anthony Noto, said his company is prepared to extend personal loans to consumers, should a credit-card cap be implemented.

'Relying on credit cards is expensive, but it's important not to forget that they still come with protections,' Rust said. 'They still cost less than a payday lender. It's still easier to resolve a problem with your credit card company than with a buy now, pay later company.'

Cannon makes up just a sliver of the $1.28 trillion in credit card debt in the US, and she acknowledges that other people have it worse than her. It doesn't make her situation less painful. She physically cannot work multiple jobs, and if she put all of her money toward her credit cards, she wouldn't be able to maintain her property and afford her basic needs. 'I never thought I would be in this position,' Cannon said. 'I'm just surviving.'
